bibl.title: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, November 5, 1954

div1.p: Mrs. Carroll is unable to meet with Hench, she is ill and lives with relatives in Maryland. All of James Carroll's papers are stored for safe-keeping. She is anxious to come to an agreement about the papers with her sisters-in-laws because she claims to be fed up with the whole business.

div1.head: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, November 5, 1954
div1.opener:
Letter post marked Mount Raimer, and
mailed Nov 8, 1954
No address given
November 5, 1954.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I received your letter of October 26, 1954 with reference to photostat-
ing the papers mentioned.

I will not be home so will not be able to see you at this time. I have
people living in my house now and have stored the papers for safe-keeping.
I thought it best to do this as I am having the worst flare-up of arthritis
I have ever had. It has settled in my right hand and shoulder rendering
me practically helpless. I am under Doctor's care, taking shots, cortisone,
etc. If I do not improve soon, I will have to go to a hospital as I do not
want to impose on relatives too long. I am very despondent and discouraged
for there is no cure for arthritis and the pain is unbearable at times.

I might add that since the embarrassment in connection with the pre-
sentation of the medal at the Cuban Embassy, I refuse to take part in
any affairs of that kind from now on and have told my sisters-in-law so.

Please mail the papers I loaned you to my home adress as the people
living there take care of my mail. I am in Maryland now but as I said
before, I may have to go to a hospital soon.

I wish the sisters-in-law would come to some agreement about these
papers as I am fed up with the whole business. I explained the circumstances
to you when you were here.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, Mrs. G. S. H. Carroll. By: fm
